newsitem.title: CHINA: Shanghai T-bill repo rates end down, spots mixed.
newsitem.headline: Shanghai T-bill repo rates end down, spots mixed.

text.p: Contracts on the treasury bill repurchase market in Shanghai closed mostly down on Friday with sentiment being hurt due to the recent crackdown on the stock markets, traders said.
But the annual rate for the most actively traded seven-day contract closed unchanged at 12 percent due to heavy new domestic A share issues, they said.
Total turnover of the six-contract market fell sharply to 6.55 million lots from 9.6 million lots.
One lot is 1,000 yuan face value of treasury bills.
Traders said the recent crackdown on the stock markets had made sentiment on the repo market cautious.
"Sharp fluctuations in stock prices have made traders cautious, preventing many institutions from trading on the repo market," one trader said.
Three new A share issues on the Shanghai and Shenzhen stock exchanges on Friday boosted activity in early-maturing contracts, traders said.
Traders said the trend next week would very much depend on the performance of the stock markets.
Contracts on the T-bill spot market in Shanghai ended mixed on Friday with the recent crackdown on the stock markets making investors cautious on the spot market as well, traders said.
The most actively traded three-year bond that matures in 1999 fell to 108.60 yuan from 108.68 yuan.
Combined volume of the seven-contract market fell sharply to 509,708 lots from 918,726 lots.
"The recent volatility on the stock markets has made investors cautious with money flowing out of all the capital markets, including the spot market," one trader said.
